canonical_explanation.text: Agriculture is the science of cultivating plants and rearing animals for food, fibre, and other products. Crops are plants grown on a large scale for food or commercial use. Kharif crops are sown in the rainy season (June-October) and include paddy, maize, soybean, and cotton. Rabi crops are sown in the winter season (October-March) and include wheat, gram, peas, and mustard. Crop production involves several steps: preparation of soil (ploughing, levelling), sowing seeds at proper depth and spacing, adding manure or fertilisers, irrigation, protecting crops from weeds and pests, and finally harvesting and storage. Manure is an organic substance obtained from decomposition of plant and animal waste, while fertilisers are chemical substances manufactured in factories. Proper storage of harvested grains is essential to protect them from moisture and pests.
rules: Kharif crops are sown in the rainy season (June-October): examples include paddy, maize, soybean.
Rabi crops are sown in the winter season (October-March): examples include wheat, gram, mustard.
Preparation of soil involves loosening and turning by ploughing.
Good quality seeds should be sown at correct depth and spacing.
Manure is organic, made from decomposed plant and animal waste.
Fertilisers are chemical substances (e.g., urea, NPK) made in factories.
Irrigation is the supply of water to crops at appropriate intervals.
Weeding is the removal of unwanted plants (weeds) from the field.
Harvesting is cutting of mature crop; threshing separates grain from chaff.
Proper storage protects grains from moisture, insects, rats, and microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a kharif crop?
questions.explanation_correct: Paddy is a kharif crop, sown in the rainy season (June-October). It requires plenty of water for growth and is harvested during the autumn months.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, gram, and mustard are all rabi crops sown during the winter season (October-March). Paddy is the correct answer as it is a kharif crop that grows during the monsoon season.

questions.question_text: Rabi crops are sown in which season?
questions.explanation_correct: Rabi crops are sown in the winter season, typically from October to March. Examples include wheat, gram, peas, and mustard.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rabi crops are not sown in the rainy, summer, or spring seasons. They are specifically winter crops sown between October and March. Kharif crops, in contrast, are sown during the rainy season.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a rabi crop?
questions.explanation_correct: Maize is a kharif crop sown during the rainy season, not a rabi crop. Wheat, gram, and peas are all rabi crops sown during the winter season.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, gram, and peas are all rabi crops. Maize is the odd one out as it is a kharif crop grown during the monsoon season (June-October).

questions.question_text: The practice of growing crops on a large scale is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Agriculture is the practice of growing crops and rearing animals for food, fibre, and other products on a large scale. It is the backbone of the Indian economy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Horticulture is the cultivation of garden plants (fruits, vegetables, flowers). Silviculture deals with forest management. Sericulture is the rearing of silkworms. Agriculture is the broad term for crop cultivation.

questions.question_text: A farmer sows cotton seeds in June and harvests the crop in October. This crop is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cotton sown in June and harvested in October falls in the kharif crop category, as kharif crops are grown during the rainy season from June to October.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the crop is sown in June and harvested in October, it falls in the monsoon season, making it a kharif crop. Rabi crops are sown in winter (October-March). While cotton is also a cash crop, the classification asked here is based on the growing season.

questions.question_text: The first step in crop production is:
questions.explanation_correct: Preparation of soil is the first step in crop production. It involves loosening and turning the soil using tools like a plough or cultivator to allow roots to penetrate deep and breathe easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sowing, irrigation, and harvesting all come after soil preparation. The correct sequence starts with preparation of soil, followed by sowing, then adding manure/fertilisers, irrigation, weeding, and finally harvesting.

questions.question_text: Which tool is used for ploughing the field?
questions.explanation_correct: A plough is used for ploughing (tilling) the field. It loosens and turns the soil, bringing nutrient-rich lower layers to the top and burying weeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A seed drill is used for sowing seeds. A sickle is used for harvesting (cutting crops). A sprinkler is used for irrigation. The plough is specifically designed for turning and loosening the soil.

questions.question_text: A seed drill is used for:

options.text: Sowing seeds at uniform depth and spacing

questions.explanation_correct: A seed drill is a modern tool used for sowing seeds at uniform depth and spacing. It ensures proper distribution of seeds and saves time compared to manual sowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A seed drill is not used for ploughing (that uses a plough), removing weeds (that is weeding), or harvesting (that uses a harvester or sickle). Its specific function is to sow seeds uniformly.

questions.question_text: Why is it important to loosen the soil before sowing seeds?

options.text: To make the field look neat
To allow roots to penetrate easily and improve aeration
To remove all the water from the soil
To increase the temperature of the soil

questions.explanation_correct: Loosening the soil is important because it allows roots to penetrate deeper into the soil easily. Loose soil also has better aeration, which helps roots breathe, and allows water to seep in effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loosening the soil is not about appearance, removing water, or increasing temperature. Its primary purpose is to enable root penetration and improve air circulation within the soil, which is essential for healthy plant growth.

questions.question_text: Before sowing, seeds are placed in water. Seeds that float are rejected because:

options.text: They are too heavy to germinate
They are damaged or hollow and will not germinate

questions.explanation_correct: Seeds that float in water are typically damaged, hollow, or not viable. Healthy seeds are dense and sink in water, which is why floating seeds are rejected before sowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Floating seeds are not too heavy (they are actually lighter), do not absorb too much water, and have not already germinated. They float because they are hollow or damaged inside, making them unfit for germination.

questions.question_text: Which agricultural tool is an improvement over the traditional plough for breaking large clumps of soil?
questions.explanation_correct: A cultivator is a modern tool driven by a tractor that can break up large clumps of soil, loosen the soil thoroughly, and prepare the field much faster than traditional ploughs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sickle is used for cutting crops. A hoe is used for removing weeds and loosening soil on a smaller scale. A seed drill is for sowing seeds. The cultivator is specifically designed as a modern upgrade to the plough for thorough soil preparation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a difference between manure and fertiliser?

options.text: Manure is chemical; fertiliser is organic
Manure is organic; fertiliser is chemical

questions.explanation_correct: Manure is an organic substance made from decomposed plant and animal waste, while fertilisers are chemical substances manufactured in factories. This is a key difference between the two.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Manure is not chemical, and fertiliser is not organic. They differ in their origin: manure comes from natural decomposition of organic matter, while fertilisers like urea and NPK are synthetically produced in factories.

questions.question_text: The supply of water to crops at appropriate intervals is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Irrigation is the process of supplying water to crops at appropriate intervals. Different methods like moat, chain pump, sprinkler, and drip irrigation are used depending on water availability and crop type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Harvesting is cutting mature crops. Weeding is removing unwanted plants. Sowing is planting seeds. Irrigation specifically refers to the systematic supply of water to agricultural fields.

questions.question_text: Which is a modern method of irrigation?
questions.explanation_correct: Drip irrigation is a modern method where water drips slowly to the roots of plants through a network of pipes. It saves water and is very efficient, especially for fruit trees and garden plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Moat, chain pump, and rahat are all traditional methods of irrigation that have been used for centuries. Drip irrigation is a modern technique that uses pipes and emitters to deliver water directly to plant roots.

questions.question_text: Excessive use of fertilisers is harmful because it:

options.text: Makes the soil more fertile permanently
Causes water pollution and reduces soil fertility over time
Increases the water-holding capacity of soil

questions.explanation_correct: Excessive use of chemical fertilisers causes water pollution when they run off into water bodies. Over time, they also reduce soil fertility by killing beneficial soil organisms and making the soil less productive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excessive fertiliser use does not permanently improve soil fertility; it actually degrades it. It kills beneficial microorganisms rather than helping them grow, and does not improve water-holding capacity. The chemicals wash into rivers and lakes, causing pollution.

questions.question_text: A farmer uses a system where water falls on plants like rain from rotating nozzles attached to pipes. This method of irrigation is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A sprinkler system has rotating nozzles attached to pipes that spray water on crops like rain. It is useful for uneven land where canals and other methods are not practical.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drip irrigation delivers water slowly through emitters directly to roots, not through rotating nozzles. Flood and furrow irrigation involve flooding the field or channels with water. The sprinkler system is the one that mimics rainfall using nozzles.

questions.question_text: Why is manure considered better for the soil than chemical fertilisers in the long run?

options.text: It provides nutrients faster than fertilisers
It improves soil texture, water-holding capacity, and supports soil organisms
It does not contain any nutrients

questions.explanation_correct: Manure improves soil texture and structure, increases water-holding capacity, and supports beneficial soil organisms. It adds organic matter (humus) to the soil, making it healthier in the long run compared to chemical fertilisers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Manure actually provides nutrients more slowly than chemical fertilisers. It is not manufactured (it is made from decomposition). It does contain nutrients, though in lower concentrations. Its key advantage is improving overall soil health.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements about weeding is correct?
(i) Weeds compete with crop plants for water, nutrients, and sunlight.
(ii) Weeding is done before sowing.
(iii) Weedicides are chemicals that kill weeds without harming crop plants.
(iv) Tilling helps in uprooting weeds.
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (iii), and (iv) are correct. Weeds compete with crops for resources, weedicides selectively kill weeds, and tilling helps uproot weeds. Statement (ii) is incorrect because weeding is done after the crop has grown, not before sowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (ii) is incorrect. Weeding is done after sowing when weeds grow alongside the crop plants. It is not done before sowing. The other three statements accurately describe weed competition, weedicide function, and the role of tilling.

questions.question_text: Cutting of the mature crop is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Harvesting is the process of cutting the mature crop from the field. It can be done manually using a sickle or by machines called harvesters (combine harvesters).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tilling is loosening the soil. Sowing is planting seeds. Winnowing is the process of separating grain from chaff using wind. Harvesting specifically refers to cutting the mature crop.

questions.question_text: The process of separating grain from chaff is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Threshing is the process of separating grains from the harvested crop (stalks). It can be done manually by beating the crop or using machines called threshers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Harvesting is cutting the crop. Sowing is planting seeds. Irrigation is watering crops. Threshing specifically refers to separating the edible grain from the stalk and husk.

questions.question_text: Harvested grains should be dried before storage to:
questions.explanation_correct: Drying grains before storage reduces their moisture content, which prevents the growth of microorganisms (fungi, bacteria) that thrive in moist conditions and can spoil the stored grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drying reduces weight (not increases it), does not change taste or colour significantly. The primary purpose is to lower moisture content so that microorganisms cannot grow and spoil the grains during storage.

questions.question_text: In large-scale grain storage, silos and granaries are used. Which factor is most critical to control in these storage facilities?
questions.explanation_correct: Moisture and pest infestation are the most critical factors to control in grain storage. High moisture promotes fungal growth and spoilage, while pests like insects and rats consume and contaminate the stored grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light intensity, sound vibrations, and wind speed are not major concerns in grain storage. The key challenges are keeping grains dry (low moisture) and protecting them from pests like insects, rats, and microorganisms.

questions.question_text: A farmer grows both crops and rears cattle for milk and eggs. This combined practice is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Mixed farming involves both growing crops and rearing animals on the same farm. The farmer benefits from both crop production and animal products like milk and eggs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Horticulture is growing garden plants. Sericulture is rearing silkworms. Pisciculture is fish farming. Mixed farming specifically means combining crop cultivation with animal husbandry on the same farm.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following crops:
(i) Wheat
(ii) Paddy
(iii) Soybean
(iv) Mustard
Which of these are kharif crops?
questions.explanation_correct: Paddy (ii) and soybean (iii) are kharif crops sown during the rainy season (June-October). Wheat and mustard are rabi crops sown during the winter season (October-March).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat (i) and mustard (iv) are rabi crops, not kharif crops. Kharif crops are grown during the monsoon season and include paddy, maize, soybean, groundnut, and cotton.

questions.question_text:
Match the following agricultural tools with their uses:
(a) Plough - (i) Sowing seeds uniformly
(b) Seed drill - (ii) Removing weeds
(c) Hoe - (iii) Turning and loosening soil
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matches are: Plough is used for turning and loosening soil (iii), Seed drill is used for sowing seeds uniformly (i), and Hoe is used for removing weeds (ii).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A plough loosens and turns soil, not for sowing or weeding. A seed drill sows seeds at proper spacing and depth. A hoe has a broad blade used to pull out weeds and loosen surface soil.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Manure is preferred over fertilisers for maintaining long-term soil health.
Reason: Manure adds humus to the soil and improves its structure.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct, but reason is incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Manure adds humus (decomposed organic matter) to the soil, which improves soil structure, water retention, and microbial activity, making it better for long-term soil health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true because manure does maintain long-term soil health better than chemical fertilisers. The reason is also true and directly explains why: humus from manure improves soil texture, porosity, and beneficial organism activity.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of agricultural practices is:

options.text: Soil preparation → Sowing → Manuring and irrigation → Harvesting

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: Soil preparation (ploughing, levelling) → Sowing (planting seeds) → Adding manure/fertilisers and irrigation → Weeding → Harvesting and storage. Option B correctly represents this order.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil preparation must come first before sowing, as the soil needs to be loosened for seeds to germinate. Manuring and irrigation follow sowing to nourish the growing plants. Harvesting is always the final field operation.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements about irrigation is correct?
(i) Drip irrigation is best suited for water-scarce areas.
(ii) Sprinkler system mimics natural rainfall.
(iii) Over-irrigation can lead to waterlogging.
(iv) All crops require the same amount of water.
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Drip irrigation conserves water, sprinklers mimic rainfall, and over-irrigation causes waterlogging. Statement (iv) is wrong because different crops have different water requirements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iv) is incorrect because different crops have different water requirements. Paddy needs much more water than wheat or millets. The other three statements are all factually correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the best description of crop rotation?

options.text: Growing the same crop repeatedly in the same field
Growing different crops alternately in the same field to maintain soil fertility
Growing two crops simultaneously in the same field
Leaving the field empty for a season

questions.explanation_correct: Crop rotation is the practice of growing different crops alternately in the same field over different seasons. It helps maintain soil fertility because different crops have different nutrient requirements and some crops (like legumes) fix nitrogen in the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing the same crop repeatedly depletes specific nutrients. Growing two crops simultaneously is intercropping, not rotation. Leaving a field empty is fallowing. Crop rotation specifically means alternating different crops across seasons.

questions.question_text: Neem leaves are placed in stored grains because:

options.text: They add nutrition to the grains
They act as natural pest repellents
They improve the taste of grains
They increase the shelf life by adding moisture

questions.explanation_correct: Neem leaves are used as a natural pest repellent in grain storage. The bitter compounds in neem leaves keep insects and pests away from stored grains, providing chemical-free protection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neem leaves do not add nutrition, improve taste, or add moisture to grains. They are specifically used because of their natural insect-repelling properties, which protect stored grains from pest damage without using synthetic chemicals.

questions.question_text: Paddy and maize are examples of rabi crops.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Paddy and maize are kharif crops, sown during the rainy season (June-October). Rabi crops include wheat, gram, and mustard, sown during winter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Paddy and maize are kharif crops grown during the monsoon season, not rabi crops. Rabi crops like wheat and gram are grown during the winter season.

questions.question_text: Fertilisers are organic substances obtained from the decomposition of plant and animal waste.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Fertilisers are chemical substances manufactured in factories (e.g., urea, NPK). It is manure that is the organic substance obtained from decomposition of plant and animal waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement describes manure, not fertilisers. Fertilisers are synthetically produced chemicals like urea, ammonium sulphate, and NPK. Manure is the organic substance from decomposed plant and animal waste.

questions.question_text: A seed drill is used to sow seeds at proper depth and distance.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. A seed drill is a modern agricultural tool that sows seeds at the correct depth and uniform spacing, ensuring better germination and reducing seed wastage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A seed drill is specifically designed to place seeds at proper depth and maintain uniform distance between them. This ensures optimal germination conditions for the seeds.

questions.question_text: Winnowing is the method used to separate heavier grain particles from lighter chaff using wind.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Winnowing uses wind to separate heavier grain particles (which fall down in a heap) from lighter chaff (which is blown away by the wind).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Winnowing is indeed the method of separating grain from chaff by using wind. The heavier grains fall vertically while the lighter chaff is carried away by the wind.

questions.question_text: Drip irrigation wastes more water than traditional methods of irrigation.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Drip irrigation is one of the most water-efficient methods of irrigation. Water is delivered drop by drop directly to the roots, minimising water wastage through evaporation and runoff.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Drip irrigation actually conserves water by delivering it directly to the root zone of plants through a network of pipes and emitters. It uses significantly less water than flood or furrow irrigation methods.

questions.question_text: Growing leguminous crops like gram between two cereal crops helps restore nitrogen in the soil.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Leguminous plants like gram have nitrogen-fixing bacteria (Rhizobium) in their root nodules. Growing them between cereal crops replenishes nitrogen in the soil through crop rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Leguminous crops harbour Rhizobium bacteria in their root nodules, which fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil. This is why crop rotation with legumes helps maintain soil fertility.

questions.question_text: A combine harvester performs both harvesting and threshing operations.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. A combine harvester is a machine that combines the operations of harvesting (cutting the crop) and threshing (separating grains from the chaff) into a single process, saving time and labour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The name 'combine' comes from the fact that it combines harvesting and threshing into one operation. It cuts the crop, separates the grain, and cleans it in a single pass through the field.

questions.question_text: Crops grown in the rainy season from June to October are called ___ crops.
questions.explanation_correct: Crops grown in the rainy season from June to October are called kharif crops. Examples include paddy, maize, soybean, groundnut, and cotton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'kharif'. Kharif crops are specifically those sown during the monsoon season (June-October). Rabi crops are sown in winter. The term kharif comes from Arabic meaning 'autumn'.

questions.question_text: The process of loosening and turning the soil is called ___ or tilling.
questions.explanation_correct: The process of loosening and turning the soil is called ploughing or tilling. It is the first step in soil preparation and helps in aerating the soil and turning nutrient-rich lower layers to the top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ploughing'. Ploughing involves using a plough to turn over the upper layer of soil, bringing fresh nutrients to the surface while burying weeds and the remains of previous crops.

questions.question_text: The organic substance obtained from the decomposition of plant and animal waste is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Manure is the organic substance obtained from the decomposition of plant and animal waste. It enriches the soil with nutrients and humus, improving its texture and water-retaining capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'manure'. Manure is formed by the natural decomposition of organic matter like cow dung, plant remains, and kitchen waste. It is different from fertilisers, which are chemical substances made in factories.

questions.question_text: The process of separating grain from the harvested stalks is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Threshing is the process of separating grain from the harvested crop stalks. It can be done by beating the crop manually or using machines called threshers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'threshing'. This process separates the edible grain from the chaff and stalk. After threshing, winnowing may be done to further separate the lighter chaff from the heavier grain.

questions.question_text: In ___ irrigation, water is delivered drop by drop directly to the roots of plants.
questions.explanation_correct: In drip irrigation, water is delivered drop by drop directly to the roots of plants through a network of pipes and emitters. This is the most water-efficient method of irrigation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'drip'. Drip irrigation systems use pipes with small holes or emitters that release water slowly and directly at the root zone, minimising water loss through evaporation.

questions.question_text: Wheat, gram, and mustard are examples of ___ crops, sown in the winter season.
questions.explanation_correct: Wheat, gram, and mustard are examples of rabi crops. Rabi crops are sown in the winter season (October-March) and harvested in spring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'rabi'. Rabi crops are winter-season crops sown around October-November and harvested in March-April. They require relatively less water and grow well in cooler conditions.

questions.question_text: Chemical substances like urea, ammonium sulphate, and super phosphate that are added to the soil to provide specific nutrients are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fertilisers are chemical substances manufactured in factories that provide specific nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium) to the soil. Examples include urea, ammonium sulphate, and super phosphate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fertilisers'. These are industrially manufactured chemicals that supply specific plant nutrients. Unlike manure, which provides nutrients slowly along with organic matter, fertilisers deliver targeted nutrients quickly.

questions.question_text: After heavy rain, a farmer notices that the topsoil in his field has been washed away. This phenomenon is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Soil erosion is the washing away or blowing off of topsoil by water or wind. Heavy rain can carry away the nutrient-rich top layer of soil, which is harmful to agriculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tilling is intentional loosening of soil. Irrigation is watering crops. Fertilisation is adding nutrients. Soil erosion specifically refers to the natural removal of topsoil by agents like water and wind.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a method of food preservation?
questions.explanation_correct: Storing in a damp place is not a food preservation method; it actually promotes microbial growth and spoilage. Drying, adding salt/sugar, and using airtight containers are all valid preservation methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drying removes moisture. Salt and sugar create conditions unfavorable for microorganisms. Airtight containers prevent exposure to air and moisture. Storing in a damp place would encourage bacterial and fungal growth, causing spoilage.

questions.question_text: A field that has been growing wheat for three consecutive seasons is likely to become deficient in which nutrient?

options.text: Nitrogen, because wheat consumes a lot of nitrogen from the soil
Water, because wheat does not need irrigation
Sunlight, because wheat blocks the sun
Carbon dioxide, because wheat absorbs all CO2 from the air

questions.explanation_correct: Wheat is a nitrogen-demanding crop. Growing it continuously depletes nitrogen from the soil. This is why crop rotation with legumes (which fix nitrogen) is recommended after cereal crops like wheat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water availability depends on irrigation, not the crop itself. Sunlight and CO2 are not depleted by growing the same crop. The key issue is soil nutrient depletion, particularly nitrogen, when the same crop is grown repeatedly.

questions.question_text: The levelling of ploughed field is done to:

options.text: Help in uniform distribution of water during irrigation
Remove all nutrients from the soil

questions.explanation_correct: Levelling of ploughed fields is done so that water distributes evenly during irrigation. An uneven field would cause water to collect in low areas while high areas remain dry, leading to poor crop growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Levelling does not remove nutrients, increase weeds, or reduce soil depth. Its primary purpose is to create a flat surface so that water spreads uniformly across the field during irrigation, ensuring all parts of the field receive adequate water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following crops would a farmer sow in October in North India?
questions.explanation_correct: Wheat is a rabi crop sown in October-November in North India. Paddy, maize, and cotton are kharif crops sown in June-July and would already have been harvested or close to harvest by October.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paddy, maize, and cotton are kharif crops sown during the monsoon season (June-July). By October, these crops would be ready for harvest. Wheat is sown in October as a rabi (winter) crop.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of using a combine harvester?

options.text: It only harvests but does not thresh
It performs harvesting and threshing simultaneously, saving time and labour
It can only be used for kharif crops
It increases the moisture content of grains

questions.explanation_correct: A combine harvester performs both harvesting (cutting the crop) and threshing (separating grains from stalks) in a single operation, greatly saving time and labour compared to doing these operations separately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A combine harvester does both harvesting and threshing, not just harvesting. It can be used for both kharif and rabi crops. It does not increase moisture content. Its main advantage is combining two operations into one efficient process.
